Header.SearchTitle: These are some of the vendors that use the Mozilla platform, the Mozilla browser, the source code, or Mozilla development tools to create applications and other products. They fall into general categories such as "app suite", "embedded application", and "extension/add-on." You can use the sort buttons to sort newest to oldest, by company name, or by type of vendor.

Vendor.Title: MozNGW
Vendor.Synopsis: MozNGW is a Mozilla-based client for the Novell GroupWise server components.

Vendor.Title: Epiphany
Vendor.Synopsis: Epiphany is the Web browser for the GNOME desktop. It aims for simplicity and standards compliance.

Vendor.Title: Netscape 7
Vendor.Synopsis: Netscape 7.1 is the latest Netscape commercial distribution of Mozilla 1.4 for Windows, Mac OS, and Linux. Its user interface is tuned for end-users rather than developers, and it includes additional features such as AIM and a spell checker.

Vendor.Title: Borland
Vendor.Synopsis: Mozilla provides the HTML preview feature within Borland's Kylix2 IDE.

Vendor.Title: HP/Compaq
Vendor.Synopsis: The first version of Mozilla for HP-UX PA and IPF platforms is now available. HP also provides the Mozilla Web Client for Tru64 UNIX and Mozilla for OpenVMS, and its Printer Assistant product uses an embedded version of Netscape 7.0/Mozilla 1.0.1.

Vendor.Title: PTC
Vendor.Synopsis: PTC uses Gecko in PRO/Engineer Wildfire, its award-winning Web-enabled CADCAM product.

Vendor.Title: FireCast
Vendor.Synopsis: FireCast, by WireSpring Technologies, is a Linux-based platform for deploying and remotely managing networks of interactive kiosks. FireCast OS, the Linux kiosk operating system, uses embedded Mozilla browsers for everything from displaying client content to providing GUI management tools.

Vendor.Title: mozdev.org
Vendor.Synopsis: Mozdev hosts projects that provide over 100 extensions, add-ons, and Mozilla applications

Vendor.Title: Xabyl
Vendor.Synopsis: Xabyl is an editor for editing XBL files visually. It is implemented using XUL and can be installed in Mozilla.

Vendor.Title: Conectiva
Vendor.Synopsis: Conectiva is a GNU/Linux distribution targetted for Latin America. The distribution bundles Mozilla and Netscape 7.

Vendor.Title: UnitedLinux
Vendor.Synopsis: UnitedLinux is a GNU/Linux distribution targetted for enterprise markets and includes Mozilla. It combines the resources of the four founding companies: Conectiva, The SCO Group, SuSE Linux AG, and TurboLinux, Inc.

Vendor.Title: Silicon Graphics
Vendor.Synopsis: Silicon Graphics builds and distributes Mozilla with releases of their Irix Operating System

Vendor.Title: ManyOne Networks
Vendor.Synopsis: ManyOne Networks has released the Mozilla-based ManyOne Universal Browser, "a more natural, intuitive, educational and entertaining way to explore the Internet over even the slowest Internet connections."

Vendor.Title: topstyle
Vendor.Synopsis: Topstyle uses Gecko as its rendering engine in the Topstyle Pro HTML/CSS/XHTML editor.

Vendor.Title: AOL
Vendor.Synopsis: AOL for Mac integrates with a Gecko-based Web browser.

Vendor.Title: GEtax
Vendor.Synopsis: GEtax, the Geneva Tax Office in Switzerland (the local equivalent of the US IRS) is sending CDs to every taxpayer in the region to help them access their tax-filing Web application and fill in the revenue declaration form. The CD, shipped to 400,000 people, includes Mozilla 1.2.1 in French for Windows, Linux and OSX.

Vendor.Title: Camino
Vendor.Synopsis: Camino (formerly known as Chimera) is a project aimed at delivering a simple, small and fast browser for Mac OS X. Camino has a UNIX back end wed to a Cocoa front end, and embeds the Gecko layout engine.

Vendor.Title: OEOne
Vendor.Synopsis: OEOne makes an operating environment that "combines the power of Linux and Mozilla technologies" with ease of use and lots of applications.

Vendor.Title: Nokia
Vendor.Synopsis: Nokia uses Mozilla as part of its Media Terminal, a powerful infotainment center for the home combining the Internet and digital broadcasting.

Vendor.Title: IBM Web Browser
Vendor.Synopsis:
The IBM Web Browser is a port of Mozilla for OS/2 with an added spell checker and Flash plugin.
IBM also uses the Mozilla browser in its INotes Web-based mail product.

Vendor.Title: http://itos.gsfc.nasa.gov/~bugzilla/
NASA SWSI
Ecoinformatics.org
Internet2
http://bugzilla.mcs.anl.gov/voyager/
Vendor.Synopsis: Government and research projects use Bugzilla.

Vendor.Title: Clifton Labs
DecisionSoft
SGI
IBM
Wirex
Solarmetric
Vendor.Synopsis: Commercial development companies and consultants use Bugzilla for bug tracking and project management tasks.

Vendor.Title: Arizona U.
MIT
CMU
mq.edu.au
UTexas
dstc.edu.au
WSU
seis.sc.edu
Stanford
Scripps
doc.wustl.edu
Cornell
Vendor.Synopsis: Universities use Bugzilla.

Vendor.Title: W3.org
Apache
OSDL
Ximian
Open SSH
Issueszilla
Horde
OpenDarwin
handhelds.org
KDE
Vendor.Synopsis: Several open source projects use Bugzilla for bug tracking.

Vendor.Title: Red Hat
SuSE
Mandrake
Gentoo
Tera Soft Solutions
Vendor.Synopsis: Red Hat, Mandrake, SuSE, Gentoo, and Tera Soft use Bugzilla for tracking bugs in their Linux development efforts.

Vendor.Title: Bugopolis
Vendor.Synopsis: Bugopolis has developed a complete hardware/software solution for bug tracking within any organization that includes Bugzilla as its foundation.

Vendor.Title: Red Hat Linux
Vendor.Synopsis: Red Hat Linux is a distribution of the Linux operating system which comes packaged with a variety of applications, including Mozilla.

Vendor.Title: Compuserve
Vendor.Synopsis: Compuserve embeds Gecko in version 7.0 of its client.

Vendor.Title: Sun Netscape 7
Vendor.Synopsis: Sun Netscape 7 is the Solaris port of the latest Internet client suite from Netscape.

Vendor.Title: Komodo
Vendor.Synopsis: ActiveState Komodo is a cross-platform integrated development environment (IDE) for scripting languages. It is built on the Mozilla platform.

Vendor.Title: Linspire
Vendor.Synopsis: Linspire (formally known as LindowsOS) is an easy-to-use, Windows-like operating system that's being sold on PCs at large retailers like Walmart, and it features Mozilla.

Vendor.Title: Ximian GNOME
Vendor.Synopsis: Ximian GNOME is an easy-to-use desktop environment for Linux and UNIX users. It includes Mozilla.

Vendor.Title: Debian
Vendor.Synopsis: Debian is a Linux distribution bundled with many applications, including Mozilla.

Vendor.Title: Fabula
Vendor.Synopsis: Fabula is a project aimed at supporting bilingual learning and literacy in primary schools in lesser-used language speaking communities in Europe. Fabula has produced a set of easy-to-use software for making and interacting with bilingual multimedia storybooks, allowing teachers and their children to combine texts in two languages, interactive images, sounds, on-screen wordlists and word games into rich and entertaining learning resources.

Vendor.Title: Galeon
Vendor.Synopsis: Galeon is a GNOME Web browser based on Gecko (the Mozilla rendering engine). It's fast and it has a light interface.

Vendor.Title: K-Meleon
Vendor.Synopsis: K-Meleon is light and fast Web browser for Windows, based on Gecko (the Mozilla rendering engine).

Vendor.Title: Nautilus
Vendor.Synopsis: Nautilus is a GNOME file manager integrated with a Gecko-based Web browser.

Vendor.Title: Beonex
Vendor.Synopsis: Beonex is an internet client software suite targetted at end-users, individual and business, with emphasis on user security and privacy.

Vendor.Title: DocZilla
Vendor.Synopsis: DocZilla is a Mozilla-based With browser with extended XML/SGML parsing and rendering capabilities.

Vendor.Title: Nvu
Vendor.Synopsis: Nvu is a Mozilla-based HTML editor for Linux and Windows. It is being developed by Daniel Glazman under the lead sponsorship of Linspire, Inc.. Nvu is a powerful Web authoring system which includes an ftp site manager and CaScadeS, a CSS editor (available for Mozilla Composer as an extension).
